name: D-salicin
Reason: 1,1':4',1''-Terphenyl has a melting point of 205 degrees Celsius. The basic unit for our comparison will be benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C (according to the CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 49th Edition, 1968-1969). The structural modifications we need to consider are the presence of two additional phenyl rings. Phenyl groups, when connected to a benzene ring, tend to increase the melting point due to the enhancement of the crystalline structure and the increase in molecular weight. In the case of D-salicin, we have two additional phenyl rings linked in a linear fashion, which would notably augment the melting point. Each additional phenyl group can be estimated to add approximately 100°C to the melting point due to increased pi-pi interactions, rigidity, and molecular weight. Additionally, the presence of a methoxy group can raise the melting point by approximately +20 degrees Celsius due to the increased molecular weight and van der Waals forces. The carbamate group can also contribute to the melting point, estimated at around +10 degrees Celsius due to the presence of a nitrogen atom, which can participate in hydrogen bonding and increase the crystal lattice stability.
